Controlling measures of micro-plastic and nano pollutants: A short review of disposing waste toners
Jujun Ruan⁎, Baojia Qin, Jiaxin Huang Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Environmental Pollution Control and Remediation Technology, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, 135 Xingang Xi Road, Guangzhou 510275, People's Republic of China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Handling Editor: Robert Letcher
Keywords: Micro-plastic Nano pollutant Pollution Vacuum gasification condensation Safe disposal
A B S T R A C T
Micro-plastic and nano-particle have been the focal pollutants in environmental science. The printer toner is omitted micro-plastic and nano pollutant. It is comprised of micro polyacrylate styrene and nano-Fe3O4 particles. Polyacrylate styrene and nano-metal were proved to be irreversibly toxic to biological cells. Therefore, toners have the potential environmental risk and healthy harm due to include micro plastics and nano-metal. To our knowledge, few studies provided the specific collection and treatment of micro-plastic pollutant. This paper has chosen a kind of micro-plastic and nano pollutant toxic toner and provided technical guidance and inspiration for controlling the micro-plastic and nano pollutants. The method of vacuum-gasification-condensation was adopted for controlling the micro-plastic and nano pollutant toner. We believe this review will open up a potential avenue for controlling micro-plastic and nano pollutants for environmental protection.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Micro-plastic and nano-particle are widely used in various fields, such as drug carriers, semiconductors, clothing and cosmetics ect, involved various aspects of the social production and life. However, the security of micro-plastic and nano-particle appears to be ambiguous and unoptimistic (Nel et al., 2006; Nel et al., 2009). A large number of non-degradable plastics enter the marine environment and progressively evolve into micro plastic particles (< 1mm) or even smaller (Law and Thompson, 2014; Julia, 2014; Sacha, 2016). On the other hand, nanotechnology is widely used in electronic products. However, with the increasing amount of electronic wastes, nanotechnology has begun to expose the negative effects, such as toner particles in the printers. Toner will release volatile particulate contaminants in printing process, such as mirco-polyester, nano-Fe3O4 and SiO2. Meanwhile, toner can cause critical contamination once it enters the soil (Ruan et al., 2013). Therefore, this focus is directed towards that how to control and deal with such a large amount of potential discarded toner particles. Currently, the researches on the risk of nanoparticle mainly involves the investigation and ecological or human health risk assessment, concretely focusing on their environmental behavior, ecological effects and nanotoxicology (Ivask et al., 2014; Puzyn et al., 2011; Tsang et al., 2017). Few studies offered the technology of specific collection and treatment of micro-plastic and nanoparticle pollutants. This study aims at proposing representative collection methods and treatment
technologies of a novel micro-plastic and nano pollutant toxic toner particles, and provided inspiration for controlling micro-plastic and nano pollutants.

sections.heading: 2.1. Waste toner
sections.text:
The waste toner obtained from the recycled waste toner cartridge. The initial contents of toner were shown in Table 1.
The toner was composed of four parts including polyacrylate styrene copolymer, ethylene-propylene copolymer, Fe3O4, and SiO2. Among them, polyacrylate styrene copolymer accounted for 55–60%, as the main organic component of the waste toner, Fe3O4 accounted for 25–30%, as the main inorganic component of the waste toner.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization methods
sections.text:
Thermal field emission scanning electron microscope (Quanta 400F) was employed to show the morphology and particle size of toner particles. sections.heading: 3.2. Observations of the internal section of toner particles
sections.text: Tweaking of the toner particles was done under an ultrathin microtome (Leica, EM UC6/FC6). The epoxy resin was used to infiltrate and embed the toner for 72 h, and then the flakes were obtained using a 230 mesh carbon-plated copper mesh. Slice samples were observed with a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, Zeiss/ Bruker, Gemini 500). The Inlens probe and the Esb probe were employed, which enable imaging of the topography of the sample with a high resolution at low voltages.

sections.heading: 4. Results
sections.text:
According to our recent work, we proposed a set of technology to recover and dispose the waste toner. First, we have established and validated a production line for recovering resources from waste toner cartridges (Ruan et al., 2013; Ruan et al., 2011; Ruan and Xu, 2011). Waste toner cartridge contains materials with different physical properties, including 8 wt% residual toners, 45 wt% magnet metals, 12 wt% aluminum and 35 wt% plastics (Ruan and Xu, 2012). The recovery process involved shearing process, magnetic separation, and eddy current separation. The recovery process was shown in Fig. 1, the waste
toners were separated by cyclone separator, the magnet metals were separated by magnetic separator, and the aluminum and the plastics were separated by Eddy current separator. The waste toner cartridges are crushed to 10mm or less of particle size in crusher. Then the mixture of crushed toner cartridges was sent into the magnetic separator. In the two processes, the cyclone separator directly connected with the crusher and magnetic separator, under the action of wind, the waste toners were separated from the mixed crushed cartridges. We improved cyclone separator that make it can provide a negative pressure during the separation, improving the recovery efficiency and avoiding diffusion of toners into environment (Ruan et al., 2011). Moreover, we conducted an environmental benefit analysis of the above production line. The crushing and separation processing employed the airtight and soundproof design. Noise emission level reduced to 67.6 dB (A), meeting the control standard of industry and business enterprise (GBJ87-1985) (GBJ87-1985) in China. TSP tests showed that organic components were safe at 0.026mg/m3, without toner leaking into the environment, meeting the first level criterion of National Ambient Air Quality Standard (GB 3095-2012) in China (Ruan et al., 2013). We had demonstrated that the collection efficiency of toners in this line is up to 95%, and the other 5% remain in the closed system. The total working power of the production line was 190 kW/h, the recovery capacity was 500 kg/h and the recovery rate was 98.2%. Waste toner cartridges are usually replaced and remanufactured by specialized companies, so it provides the feasibility to gather the residual toners in cartridges for centralized treatment.
Toners are the major environmental pollutant of waste toner cartridges and they easily spread into the air due to their non-agglomeration and insolubility in liquid properties partly due to the toner particle size in 5 μm. In order to prevent from diffusing into the environment again, we innovatively adopted vacuum gasification to obtain the harmless and high value-added recycling of toners. Under high temperature and vacuum conditions, the hazardous toner was heated. When the temperature reached a certain value, the organic components
were pyrolyzed and transformed into small molecular organics, the small molecular organics would evaporate and escape from the heating area, then these small molecular organics were condensed in the condensation area. Through the vacuum gasification, the organic components coated on nanoscale metal oxides were separated, and the condensed oil can be collected as resources (Ruan et al., 2017). Furthermore, according to the results of TG and TG-FTIR, the thermodynamic properties of the vacuum gasification of the waste toner were concluded as follows: the apparent activation energy E and frequency factor A were 12.547 kJ/mol and 10,148.120 min−1 respectively by kinetics analysis. At the temperature of 773 K, the residence time of 40min and heating rate of 15 Kmin−1 were significant and sufficient to obtain maximum oil yield, meaning the complete separation of microplastics from nanometal particles (Dong et al., 2017). The vacuum gasification process of toners was of great industrial interest, accompanied by the fully recycling of metal oxide nanomaterials without effects by carbon thermal reduction. Meanwhile, this technique was extremely effective to prevent a large number of potential toner pollutants into the environment. In summary, this study provided resource-based technology approaches for waste toners and technical enlightenments for various nanomaterials contaminants in the environment.
Furthermore, in the vacuum-gasification process of polyacrylate
styrene in waste toner, the existence of Fe3O4 and SiO2 particles had many positive significances. In Fig. 2a, a large-scope image of the integral ultrathin section showed that Fe3O4 particles in toners were formed by the agglomeration of smaller Fe3O4 nanoparticles, because the nano-Fe3O4 as a magnetic material was easy to reunion, caused the surface of nano-Fe3O4 agglomerates more rough. Additionally, the nano-Fe3O4 agglomerates were distributed randomly and embedded in the polyester. By observing the nano-Fe3O4 particles can be obtained that the particle sizes of nano-Fe3O4 particles were mainly focus on 10 to 30 nm, some studies indicated nano-Fe3O4 particles with particle size from 10 to 30 nm had high catalytic performance (Gawande et al., 2013). Meanwhile, the hollow structures inside the nano-Fe3O4 agglomerates were observed, it indicated that a large specific surface area on the surface of nano-Fe3O4 agglomerates. Fig. 2b indicated the mapping images of the cutting surface, suggesting that merely a relatively small number of SiO2 particles were randomly distributed, the particle size was small and less than the lower limit of observation.
In Fig. 2c, we simulated the distribution of the nano-Fe3O4 and nano-SiO2 particles on the surface of polyester. In the vacuum gasification process, the existence of nanometals increased thermal conductivity and heat capacity of toners, leading to the acceleration of heat transfer in toners. Fig. 2a shown the nano-Fe3O4 agglomerates owned a
large specific surface area and poor smooth surface, the large specific surface area and the poor smooth surface of nano-Fe3O4 promoted the contact surface with more organic free-radical contact with each other, and promoted polyester decomposition (Velzeboer et al., 2014). On the other hand, Fig. 2a and b shown the nano-Fe3O4 and nano-SiO2 owned smaller particle sizes, the decreased size of the nano-oxides made their surface activity increase and the electron binding energy decrease (Brock, 2004). And there were more free electrons generation on the interface with organic radicals, accelerating the electron transfer rate during the decomposition reaction, it can promote the process of the polyester decomposition. In a word, the existence of Fe3O4 and SiO2 particles made the polyacrylate styrene vacuum-gasification process more uniform, stable and concentrated, which was significant and necessary for the harmlessness and recycling of toners.

sections.heading: 5. Discussion
sections.text:
Toner particles in printers are a novel micro-plastic and nano-particle pollutant, it's close to our life and work. In China, the production of toners was about 138.8 thousand tons in 2016, about 10% of toners were wasted. It is representative that the toners have potential nanotoxicity that cannot be ignored due to their free diffusion and micron size (Barnard, 2010). The toner particles are made of nano-Fe3O4 and nano-SiO2 particles coated by the polyacrylate styrene, and the specific structures are shown in Fig. 3 (Ruan et al., 2013). Because of indoor air is stable, the toxic nanoscale contaminants and volatile irritant gas exist indoor more persistently. It is confirmed that the nano-Fe3O4 and polyacrylate styrene components are irreversibly detrimental to the human body, which is manifested as the permanently damage to
respiratory system and even invasion of the lymphatic and epithelial tissues (Michael, 2016; Grafmueller et al., 2015). Furthermore, the volatile nanoparticles have the characteristics of large specific surface area and strong hydrophobicity, as carriers promoting the enrichment and migration of other heavy metals and persistent organic pollutants in the air (Velzeboer et al., 2014). As an essential member of waste electrical and electronic equipment, waste toners can cause huge hazards in their short life-cycles. Recently, policy and law in China have prohibited the import of e-wastes including waste toner cartridges. Herein, other countries urgently need to develop their own treatment technology for waste toner cartridges.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text:
Toners, as traditional office supplies, had been proved as potential environmental hazardous pollutants (Kwon et al., 2017). Manufacturers were advised to design more closed printer structures and more environment-friendly materials to support and promote the upgrading of green printers. And printers were suggested for placing in isolated rooms to avoid the hazardous toner was emitted during the printing process, thereby causing the exposure of nano-Fe3O4, nano-SiO2 and micro plastics, micro contaminants were dispersed and volatilized into the indoor air and human body. It was a long-term objective to eliminate the diffusion of organic gases and nano-inorganic particles into the environment. Herein, this study provided technical guidance and inspiration for recovering micro-plastic and nano pollutants in the environment. The physical and thermal treatment methods were safe and green during the treatment process, with no secondary pollution induced. We believe that our strategy will open up a potential avenue for
the controlling of micro-plastic and nano pollutants in applications of environmental protection.
